awd_titl_txt: Plants as Pollution Sentinels for Improved Health in the Built Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET 1336877
Joel G. Burken
Missouri University of Science and Technology

Vascular plants interact intimately with their surroundings, extracting water, nutrients and contaminants from the ground. The ability to draw in contaminants allows plants to act as sensors of environmental pollution below the ground and also in buildings. If contamination is present in the ground near a building, contaminant vapors can move through soil and transport into the building in a process known as vapor intrusion. Vapor intrusion into homes can pose a considerable health risk. This project will improve our understanding of how pollutants move between soil, plants and buildings, and how time and distance affect outcomes. Currently, assessing the threat of vapor intrusion is expensive and slow, particularly when compared to the use of plants as biosensors. The core hypothesis is that plants are very good at identifying areas of vapor intrusion risk, as vegetation occupies a similar environmental volume as residential buildings, both below and above ground. In this project, plants will be studied in a greenhouse and at currently contaminated field sites to determine how rapidly plants draw in soil pollution. In field studies, we will determine the 3-dimensional volume sampled by plant roots. The knowledge gained will better define contaminant fate and transport in the environment, particularly in vapor intrusion scenarios where pollution is not uniformly distributed in the soil. A better understanding of contaminant dynamics and interactions between plants and the environment will lead to more accurate ways of predicting potential risks to people in their homes. In addition to these scientific advances, new methods, both analytical and statistical, will be developed and applied with particular focus on vapor intrusion. This research will span from the fundamental molecular scale, to multimedia contaminant transport, to full scale systems that span the four dimensions of space and time. 

The field of phytoforensics excels at assessing threats rapidly and inexpensively.  This is of great benefit to public health, particularly in areas where the economic incentive and public knowledge are lacking. Additionally, the mere presence of a drill rig and workers in protective gear creates the image of guilt for potentially responsible parties and could raise unwarranted concerns. These phytoforensic methods for vapor intrusion will not require entering homes for initial assessments, thereby greatly reducing the potentially unnecessary alarm or intrusion into personal space. The data and methods will be shared broadly and distributed in the US and internationally, among eight partner nations, via the ?Pollution Investigations by Trees? (PIT) program of which the PI is a founding partner. The broad and rapid dissemination will lead to results of this endeavor impacting many researchers and their efforts in delineating and remediating environmental pollutants as part of the global effort to protect human health. Collectively, knowledge of plant-contaminant interactions in time and space will be applied to sites with previously characterized vapor intrusion to model the performance of plants as vapor intrusion biosensors. If successful, this project will provide a low-cost, sustainable screening tool to rapidly anticipate threats to inhabitants at contaminated sites, thereby protecting a much larger population of at-risk residents.

por.por_cntn:
The project Plants as Pollution Sentinels for Improved Health in the Built Environment was completed to generate knowledge of plant-soil-water-vapor-building interactions. The work is of direct interest and need nationally, as vapor intrusion, i.e. subsurface intrusion, is under great scrutiny and current assessments are time and resource intensive, and of limited value in heterogeneous settings. EPA1 noted “Subsurface intrusion can result in people being exposed to harmful levels of hazardous substances, which can raise the lifetime risk of cancer or chronic disease.” This project specifically advances fundamental knowledge of and methods for using phytoforensic methods to estimate vapor intrusion (VI) risk, as plants inherently adapt to heterogeneities in the subsurface while averaging contaminant concentrations over a time and space analogous to the scale of VI.  The project had four specific objectives, and all were accomplished.

The first (1) objective was to quantify the transient nature of plant-contaminant concentrations to evaluate different plants’ suitability as biomonitors.  Contaminant uptake by plants is dependent on fundamental processes, such as transpiration and chemical partitioning/retardation/diffusivity in plant tissues. Assessing these plant processes in various plant types, such as trees, shrubs and grasses, and plant families will explain much of the variation observed in field application of biomonitoring. In this case, different species were assessed and we have new models of using plant type and size to better quantify VI risk.

The second objective (2) set out to assess, characterize and model long-term VOC concentration variations in field-scale experiments. Concentrations of VOCs in plants will vary over longer temporal scales due to meteorological fluctuations, an effect that is best investigated in a field setting. Modeling variations in contaminant concentrations from meteorological data will allow prediction of plant concentrations throughout the seasons and improve confidence in biomonitoring approaches.

In field work the third objective (3) was to determine the representative spatial extent, or environmental volume, sampled by plants. Estimation of plant root spread coupled with extensive soil sampling of contaminant gradients around plants in the field will allow prediction of the effective environmental volume sampled by a variety of plants. This was accomplished in concert with the fourth objective (4) which was to perform plant sampling at field sites with characterized soil gas contamination and vapor intrusion. Through plant sampling at no less than 5 sites, field-scale data was used to generate new knowledge that demonstrate subsurface volume that plant sampling methods can accomplish.  This novel model was developed at two Superfund sites where human exposure to contaminants was known to occur.  The new knowledge and methods will directly relate to more rapid assessment of field locations to limit human exposure.

The broader impacts of this work are notable, with direct impact to protecting human health. Vapor intrusion (VI) of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in the built environment is an obscure and pervasive impact to human health as carcinogenic contaminants often migrate into our living space from undetected groundwater plumes.  Current VI assessments are time-, cost-, and labor-intensive, and thereby limit application and early detection of vapor intrusion.  Vapor Intrusion was just added to the Hazard Ranking System (HRS) for evaluating contaminated sites for the National Priorities List (NPL) or better known as ‘Superfund Sites.’2 The intellectual merit of the research carried out was substantial, with 6 articles already in print and two pending.  However ,the inclusion of subsurface intrusion in the HRS will make the intellectual contributions of this work of far more benefit and impact in site investigation science and in benefit to human health directly. EPA documents noted “the Government Accountability Office (GAO) concluded that if vapor intrusion sites are not assessed and, if needed, listed on the NPL, there is the potential that contaminated sites with unacceptable human exposure will not be acted upon. GAO recommended that the EPA Administrator determine the extent to which the EPA will consider vapor intrusion in listing NPL sites and how this will affect the number of NPL sites listed in the future.” 3 

 

1 Christie St. Clair (2016) Press release: EPA Adds Subsurface Intrusion to the Superfund Hazard Ranking System https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/epa-adds-subsurface-intrusion-superfund-hazard-ranking-system

2  Federal Register / Vol. 82, No. 5 / Monday, January 9, 2017 / Rules and Regulations

3 EPA Current Updates: Federal Register Notice of Rulemaking - Addition of Subsurface Intrusion (SsI) to the HRS Released Dec 7, 2016. https://www.epa.gov/superfund/hrs-subsurface-intrusion
